title: Direct sum of left modules
content:
According to Wikipedia ("Direct sum of modules", 28-Mar-2019, ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_sum_of_modules ) "Let R be a ring, and { Mi: i ∈ I } a family of left R-modules indexed by the set I. The direct sum of {Mi} is then defined to be the set of all sequences (αi) where αi ∈ Mi and αi = 0 for cofinitely many indices i. (The direct product is analogous but the indices do not need to cofinitely vanish.)". In this definition, "cofinitely many" means "almost all" or "for all but finitely many". Furthemore, "This set inherits the module structure via componentwise addition and scalar multiplication. Explicitly, two such sequences α and β can be added by writing (α + β)i = αi + βi for all i (note that this is again zero for all but finitely many indices), and such a sequence can be multiplied with an element r from R by defining r(α)i = (rα)i for all i.".
In [Lang] p. 128, the definition of the direct sum of left modules is based on direct sums of abelian groups ("We define on [the direct sum of abelian groups Mi] M a structure of A-module: If (xi)i ∈ I is an element of M, i.e. a familiy of elements xi ∈ Mi such that xi = 0 for almost all i, and if a ∈ A, then we define a(xi)i ∈ I = (axi)i ∈ I, that is we define multiplication by a componentwise.") which itself is based on the direct product of abelian groups ([Lang] p. 36: "Let {Ai}i ∈ I be a family of abelian groups. We define their direct sum A ... to be the subset of the direct product ... consisting of all families (xi)i ∈ I with xi ∈ Ai such that xi = 0 for all but a finite number of indices i").
In short, the direct sum of a familiy of (left) modules {Mi}i ∈ I is the restriction of the direct product of {Mi}i ∈ I to the elements with index function having finite support, as formalized by the definition ~ df-dsmm .

blocks.name: cdsmm
blocks.content: Class of module direct sum generator.

blocks.name: df-dsmm
blocks.content: The direct sum of a family of Abelian groups or left modules is the induced group structure on finite linear combinations of elements, here represented as functions with finite support. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 7-Jan-2015.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-dsmm(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  |- wceq(cdsmm, cmpo(s0, s1, universe, universe, co(co(cv(s0), cprds, cv(s1)), cress, crab(s2, cixp(s3, cdm(cv(s1)), cfv(cbs, cfv(cv(s1), cv(s3)))), wcel(crab(s3, cdm(cv(s1)), wne(cfv(cv(s2), cv(s3)), cfv(c0g, cfv(cv(s1), cv(s3))))), cfn)))))
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
}
blocks.pretty:
axiom df-dsmm(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  ‚ä¢ (+)m =(s0 ‚àà ùïå, s1 ‚àà ùïå ‚Ü¶((s0[√ó]s1)[|`s]{ s2 ‚àà √ó(s3 ‚àà dom(s1),(Base `(s1 ` s3)))| { s3 ‚àà dom(s1)|(s2 ` s3)‚â†(0 `(s1 ` s3))} ‚àà Fin }))
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s3)
}

blocks.name: reldmdsmm
blocks.content: The direct sum is a well-behaved binary operator. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 7-Jan-2015.)

  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, c0)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, c2)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, c0)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, c2)
} = {
  syl(c0 ‚àà c1, (c2[(+)m]c0)=((c2[√ó]c0)[|`s]c3), c0 ‚àà ùïå)
  elex(c0, c1)
  pm2.61ian(c0 ‚àà ùïå, (c2[(+)m]c0)=((c2[√ó]c0)[|`s]c3), c2 ‚àà ùïå)
  ovmpt2a(hs0, hs1, c2, universe, c0, universe, cdsmm, ((c2[√ó]c0)[|`s]c3), ((hs0[√ó]hs1)[|`s]{ s0 ‚àà √ó(s1 ‚àà dom(hs1),(Base `(hs1 ` s1)))| { s1 ‚àà dom(hs1)|(s0 ` s1)‚â†(0 `(hs1 ` s1))} ‚àà Fin }))
  oveq12d((hs0[√ó]hs1), cress, { s0 ‚àà √ó(s1 ‚àà dom(hs1),(Base `(hs1 ` s1)))| { s1 ‚àà dom(hs1)|(s0 ` s1)‚â†(0 `(hs1 ` s1))} ‚àà Fin }, (c2[√ó]c0), c3, (hs0 = c2 ‚àß hs1 = c0))
  syl6eqr({ s0 ‚àà √ó(s1 ‚àà dom(hs1),(Base `(hs1 ` s1)))| { s1 ‚àà dom(hs1)|(s0 ` s1)‚â†(0 `(hs1 ` s1))} ‚àà Fin }, c3, { s0 ‚àà(Base `(c2[√ó]c0))| { s1 ‚àà dom(c0)|(s0 ` s1)‚â†(0 `(c0 ` s1))} ‚àà Fin }, (hs0 = c2 ‚àß hs1 = c0))
  rabeqbidv(s0, √ó(s1 ‚àà dom(hs1),(Base `(hs1 ` s1))), (Base `(c2[√ó]c0)), (hs0 = c2 ‚àß hs1 = c0), { s1 ‚àà dom(hs1)|(s0 ` s1)‚â†(0 `(hs1 ` s1))} ‚àà Fin, { s1 ‚àà dom(c0)|(s0 ` s1)‚â†(0 `(c0 ` s1))} ‚àà Fin)
  eqtr3d(√ó(s1 ‚àà dom(hs1),(Base `(hs1 ` s1))), (Base `(c2[√ó]c0)), (Base `(hs0[√ó]hs1)), (hs0 = c2 ‚àß hs1 = c0))
  prdsbas(s1, (Base `(hs0[√ó]hs1)), dom(hs1), hs1, (hs0[√ó]hs1), hs0, universe, universe, (hs0 = c2 ‚àß hs1 = c0))
  eqid((hs0[√ó]hs1))
  a1i((hs0 = c2 ‚àß hs1 = c0), hs0 ‚àà ùïå)
  vex(hs0)

  eqid((Base `(hs0[√ó]hs1)))
  eqidd(dom(hs1), (hs0 = c2 ‚àß hs1 = c0))

  oveq12(hs0, c2, hs1, c0, cprds)
  eleq1d({ s1 ‚àà dom(hs1)|(s0 ` s1)‚â†(0 `(hs1 ` s1))}, cfn, { s1 ‚àà dom(c0)|(s0 ` s1)‚â†(0 `(c0 ` s1))}, (hs0 = c2 ‚àß hs1 = c0))
  rabeqbidv(s1, dom(hs1), dom(c0), (hs0 = c2 ‚àß hs1 = c0), (s0 ` s1)‚â†(0 `(hs1 ` s1)), (s0 ` s1)‚â†(0 `(c0 ` s1)))

blocks.name: dsmmbase
blocks.content: Base set of the module direct sum. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 7-Jan-2015.)
blocks.origin:
thm dsmmbase(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, c1), wceq(c2, cfv(cbs, co(c3, cdsmm, c0))))
  -| wceq(c2, crab(s0, cfv(cbs, co(c3, cprds, c0)), wcel(crab(s1, cdm(c0), wne(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cfv(c0g, cfv(c0, cv(s1))))), cfn)))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c3)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c3)
} = {
  syl(wcel(c0, c1), wceq(c2, cfv(cbs, co(c3, cdsmm, c0))), wcel(c0, universe))
  elex(c0, c1)
  syl6reqr(c2, cfv(cbs, co(c3, cdsmm, c0)), cfv(cbs, co(co(c3, cprds, c0), cress, c2)), wcel(c0, universe))
  fveq2d(cbs, co(c3, cdsmm, c0), co(co(c3, cprds, c0), cress, c2), wcel(c0, universe))
  dsmmval(s0, s1, c0, universe, c3, c2)
  ax-mp(wceq(c2, cfv(cbs, co(co(c3, cprds, c0), cress, c2))), wss(c2, cfv(cbs, co(c3, cprds, c0))))
  ssrab3(s0, c2, cfv(cbs, co(c3, cprds, c0)), wcel(crab(s1, cdm(c0), wne(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cfv(c0g, cfv(c0, cv(s1))))), cfn))
  ressbas2(c2, cfv(cbs, co(c3, cprds, c0)), co(co(c3, cprds, c0), cress, c2), co(c3, cprds, c0))
  eqid(co(co(c3, cprds, c0), cress, c2))
  eqid(cfv(cbs, co(c3, cprds, c0)))
  diff.cfv.s(s0, cbs, co(c3, cprds, c0))
  diff.cbs.s(s0)
  diff.co.s(s0, c3, cprds, c0)
  diff.cprds.s(s0)
}

thm dsmmbase(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  ‚ä¢ (c0 ‚àà c1 ‚Üí c2 =(Base `(c3[(+)m]c0)))
  ‚ä£ c2 = { s0 ‚àà(Base `(c3[√ó]c0))| { s1 ‚àà dom(c0)|(s0 ` s1)‚â†(0 `(c0 ` s1))} ‚àà Fin }
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, c0)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, c3)

blocks.name: dsmm0cl
blocks.content: The all-zero vector is contained in the finite hull, since its support is empty and therefore finite. This theorem along with the next one effectively proves that the finite hull is a "submonoid", although that does not exist as a defined concept yet. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 11-Jan-2015.)

} = {
  mpbir2and(w0, wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c0, cfv(cbs, c2)), wcel(crab(hs0, c5, wne(cfv(c0, cv(hs0)), cfv(c0g, cfv(c4, cv(hs0))))), cfn))

  ralrimiva(hs0, c5, w0, wn(wne(cfv(c0, cv(hs0)), cfv(c0g, cfv(c4, cv(hs0))))))
  sylibr(wa(w0, wcel(cv(hs0), c5)), wn(wne(cfv(c0, cv(hs0)), cfv(c0g, cfv(c4, cv(hs0))))), wceq(cfv(c0, cv(hs0)), cfv(c0g, cfv(c4, cv(hs0)))))

  fvco2(c4, c5, cv(hs0), c0g)

blocks.content: The finite hull of a product of groups is additionally closed under negation and thus is a subgroup of the product. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 11-Jan-2015.)

blocks.name: dsmmlss
blocks.content: The finite hull of a product of modules is additionally closed under scalar multiplication and thus is a linear subspace of the product. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 11-Jan-2015.)

blocks.name: dsmmlmod
blocks.content: The direct sum of a family of modules is a module. See also the remark in [Lang] p. 128. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 11-Jan-2015.)
blocks.origin:
thm dsmmlmod(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wcel(c0, clmod))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, c2))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c3, crg))
  -| wi(w0, wf(c4, c1, clmod))
  -| wi(wa(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c1)), wceq(cfv(csca, cfv(c4, cv(s0))), c3))
  -| wceq(c0, co(c3, cdsmm, c4))
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c3)
  -| diffsc(s0, c4)
  -| diffsw(s0, w0)
} = {
  syl2anc(w0, wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(co(c3, cprds, c4), clmod), wcel(cfv(cbs, co(c3, cdsmm, c4)), cfv(clss, co(c3, cprds, c4))))
  prdslmodd(s0, co(c3, cprds, c4), c3, c4, c1, c2, w0)
  dsmmlss(s0, cfv(cbs, co(c3, cdsmm, c4)), cfv(clss, co(c3, cprds, c4)), c1, c2, c3, c4, co(c3, cprds, c4), w0)
  eqid(co(c3, cprds, c4))
  lsslmod(co(c3, cprds, c4), cfv(cbs, co(c3, cdsmm, c4)), cfv(clss, co(c3, cprds, c4)), c0)
  eqtri(c0, co(co(c3, cprds, c4), cress, cfv(cbs, co(c3, cdsmm, c4))), co(c3, cdsmm, c4))
  dsmmval2(c3, c4, cfv(cbs, co(c3, cdsmm, c4)))
  eqid(cfv(cbs, co(c3, cdsmm, c4)))
  eqid(cfv(clss, co(c3, cprds, c4)))
  diff.co.s(s0, c3, cprds, c4)
  diff.cprds.s(s0)
  diff.cfv.s(s0, cbs, co(c3, cdsmm, c4))
  diff.cbs.s(s0)
  diff.co.s(s0, c3, cdsmm, c4)
  diff.cdsmm.s(s0)
}

thm dsmmlmod(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, wff w0) {
  ‚ä¢ (w0 ‚Üí c0 ‚àà LMod)
  ‚ä£ (w0 ‚Üí c1 ‚àà c2)
  ‚ä£ (w0 ‚Üí c3 ‚àà Ring)
  ‚ä£ (w0 ‚Üí(c4 : c1 ‚Üí LMod))
  ‚ä£ ((w0 ‚àß s0 ‚àà c1)‚Üí(Scalar `(c4 ` s0))= c3)
  ‚ä£ c0 =(c3[(+)m]c4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, c1)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, c3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, c4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, w0)
} = {
  syl2anc(w0, c0 ‚àà LMod, (c3[√ó]c4)‚àà LMod, (Base `(c3[(+)m]c4))‚àà(LSubSp `(c3[√ó]c4)))
  prdslmodd(s0, (c3[√ó]c4), c3, c4, c1, c2, w0)
  dsmmlss(s0, (Base `(c3[(+)m]c4)), (LSubSp `(c3[√ó]c4)), c1, c2, c3, c4, (c3[√ó]c4), w0)
  eqid((c3[√ó]c4))
  lsslmod((c3[√ó]c4), (Base `(c3[(+)m]c4)), (LSubSp `(c3[√ó]c4)), c0)
  eqtri(c0, ((c3[√ó]c4)[|`s](Base `(c3[(+)m]c4))), (c3[(+)m]c4))
  dsmmval2(c3, c4, (Base `(c3[(+)m]c4)))
  eqid((Base `(c3[(+)m]c4)))
  eqid((LSubSp `(c3[√ó]c4)))
  diff.co.s(s0, c3, cprds, c4)
  diff.cprds.s(s0)
  diff.cfv.s(s0, cbs, (c3[(+)m]c4))
  diff.cbs.s(s0)
  diff.co.s(s0, c3, cdsmm, c4)
  diff.cdsmm.s(s0)
}
